title: Trust & Conflict Patterns
description: Discover how you build trust and handle disagreements.

questions.text: When we disagree, what's my typical pattern?
choices: I need to resolve it quickly
I want to talk it through immediately
I need time to process alone

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict patterns reveal attachment activation under stress. Quick resolvers can't tolerate disconnection; withdrawers protect themselves from overwhelm; immediate talkers process externally; alone-processors need self-regulation. These patterns often reflect childhood experiences with conflict in the family of origin.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conflict patterns create the classic pursue-withdraw cycle. The immediate-talker chases the withdrawer, who retreats further, escalating anxiety. Naming your patterns without blame is the first step to changing them.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conflict patterns can help (two withdrawers give each other space) or hurt (two immediate-talkers may escalate). Know your shared tendencies.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens in your body and mind when conflict arises? What do you instinctively do? Where did you learn this pattern?

questions.text: How easy is it for me to trust you completely?
choices: It takes time but I get there
I struggle but I'm working on it

therapeutic.rationale: Trust capacity is shaped by attachment history. Easy trusters often had secure early experiences; cautious trusters may have been hurt but recovered; slow-build trusters are protecting themselves; struggling trusters carry significant wounds. Trust is both earned in the present and influenced by the past.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust capacities require different patience levels. The easy-truster may not understand why their partner struggles; the struggling-truster may feel pressured. Meet your partner where they are with trust.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust capacity means you'll build (or struggle to build) trust at similar rates. You understand each other's relationship with trust.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How easily do you trust in relationships? Has this changed over time? What would help you trust more fully?

questions.text: What do I need when I feel insecure?

therapeutic.rationale: What soothes insecurity reveals our attachment system's needs. Verbal reassurance seekers need explicit comfort; quality-time seekers need presence; self-soothers need autonomy; physical comfort seekers need co-regulation through touch. Providing the wrong type of soothing when your partner is insecure can escalate rather than calm.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different insecurity soothing needs often clash. The verbal-reassurance seeker may feel abandoned by the self-soother's withdrawal; the self-soother may feel smothered by verbal pursuit. Ask: 'What would help right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared insecurity soothing means you'll instinctively provide what helps. You'll calm each other because you need the same thing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you feel insecure in your relationship, what helps? What makes it worse? Does your partner know what you need?

questions.text: How do I handle it when you're stressed or distant?
choices: Try to help or fix things

therapeutic.rationale: Response to partner's stress reveals attachment patterns. Space-givers trust the relationship can handle distance; fixers manage anxiety through action; worry-about-us responders have relationship-specific anxiety; check-in-not-push responders balance concern and respect. The anxious attacher's worst fear is often that their partner's bad mood is about them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different stress responses can create misattunement. The worried-about-us person may feel dismissed by the space-giver; the space-giver may feel smothered by worry. Communicate explicitly: 'My stress isn't about us.'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared stress responses mean you'll handle each other's difficult times similarly. You understand what's needed because it's what you'd need.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When your partner is stressed or distant, what's your first thought? Does your response help or add pressure? What would ideal support look like?

questions.text: What would I struggle with most if we broke up?

therapeutic.rationale: What we fear losing reveals what we're most attached to. Companionship-losers are attached to partnership itself; rejection-feelers are attached to validation; routine-missers are attached to daily rhythms; pain-feelers are attached to emotional connection. Understanding this helps clarify what the relationship provides.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different loss fears reveal different relationship functions for each of you. Your partner may fear rejection while you fear routine loss. Both are real fears worth understanding.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared loss fears suggest the relationship serves similar functions for you both. You're attached to the same aspects of being together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: If your relationship ended, what would hurt most? What does this tell you about what you value in the relationship?
